Rabbit

It works!

Congratulations! You managed to set up Rabbit successfully.
This page is the default webpage; it's displayed since you haven't put anything in the public directory.

Rabbit is confined to a single directory where it stores everything about itself, called the Rabbit root; thus, it makes it easy to, for example, serve different content over multiple ports using Rabbit.

Rabbit's root contains four main directories:

    - public: contains the files that people who visit your website can access, such as the index.html file.

    - scripts: contains scripts that Rabbit will run when someone requests a certain path or a file with a certain type; however, Rabbit will only run compiled scripts, so you need to use the netc utility to compile any scripts you want to use.

    - bin: contains executables used by your website; in this directory you can find Rabbit itself, netc, and any other carrots.

    - cache: should be mounted to a ramfs; it contains a cache where Rabbit stores files to avoid having to reload them again.
